issues.title: Alignment with RFC 9130
issues.author: DanieleIETF
issues.body:
-	We need to do a better alignment with RFC 9130 (YANG data model for IS-IS), mostly when it comes to terminology. This is a general comment I received from the people that quickly reviewed it. I’m not familiar with RFC9130 so here is a first round of comments.
o	From a quick scan RFC 9130 has the protocol level module (isis) with a part covering the interfaces, while we split the parameters into node level and termination point level. Maybe the comment is referring to the mapping between these things? Since we’re augmenting the network model we off course need to speak about node and termination point, but maybe we can add a mapping? The termination point equals the interface in IS IS right? 
o	Timer attributes: we have LSP lifetime and LSP refresh interval. In RFC9130 LSP lifetime seems to be consistent, while the LSP refresh interval seems to be simply lsp-refresh 

  feature lsp-refresh {
       description
         "Configuration of the LSP refresh interval.";
     }

o	We use level, but if I correctly understood it maps against “level-type” in RFC 9130?
o	Neighbours: we use IP address but in RFC9130 they seem to be identified via system ID
 
o	Regarding the interfaces (isis-termination-point-attributes)we have the following mapping: 
	       +--rw interface-type?   Identityref      OK
	       +--rw level?            ietf-isis:level     this should be level-type?
	       +--rw metric?           uint64  this should have 3 value: value, level-1 and level-2 rigth?
	       +--rw is-passive?       Boolean  just passive, no is.

issues.title: Protocol and interface level parameters
issues.author: DanieleIETF
issues.body: -	Question: why ISIS has LSP parameters both as protocol and interface level? I guess because there is a global protocol level that can be overridden per interface. Shouldn’t we have the same between node and termination point level?
